# Cambridge International ExaminationsCambridge International General Certificate of Secondary Education  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 170, 193, 200]]<|/det|>
CANDIDATE NAME  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 222, 170, 250]]<|/det|>
CENTRE NUMBER

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[619, 220, 720, 250]]<|/det|>
CANDIDATE NUMBER  

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[733, 214, 902, 256]]<|/det|>  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 278, 170, 292]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 298, 330, 313]]<|/det|>
Paper 6 Alternative to Practical  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[732, 278, 904, 333]]<|/det|>
0625/62February/March 20181 hour  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 339, 415, 374]]<|/det|>
Candidates answer on the Question Paper. No Additional Materials are required.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[93, 390, 386, 406]]<|/det|>
## READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 416, 718, 490]]<|/det|>
Write your Centre number, candidate number and name on all the work you hand in. Write in dark blue or black pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs. Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid. DO NOT WRITE IN ANY BARCODES.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 501, 768, 546]]<|/det|>
Answer all questions. Electronic calculators may be used. You may lose marks if you do not show your working or if you do not use appropriate units.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 555, 758, 585]]<|/det|>
At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together. The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 96, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 720, 90]]<|/det|>
A student is determining the mass of a metre rule by a balancing method.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 104, 484, 121]]<|/det|>
He is using the apparatus shown in Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[104, 133, 893, 269]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 288, 533, 305]]<|/det|>
<pre>Fig. 1.1

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 320, 148, 338]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 320, 918, 352]]<|/det|>
He places the metre rule on the pivot and then places block \(\mathbf{Q}\) with its centre at the 95.0cm mark.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 350, 855, 367]]<|/det|>
The student stated that it is difficult to place the mass accurately at the 95.0cm mark.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 380, 918, 413]]<|/det|>
Explain how the student could overcome this. You may draw a diagram to help your explanation.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[887, 598, 920, 616]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 73, 148, 90]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 918, 106]]<|/det|> The student keeps block \(\mathbf{Q}\) at the \(95.0 \text{cm}\) mark and adjusts the position of the metre rule on the pivot until the metre rule is as near to being balanced as possible. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 119, 918, 152]]<|/det|> Describe a method to find the point at which the metre rule is as near to being balanced as possible. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 304, 146, 322]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 304, 918, 337]]<|/det|> The student determines the distance \(a\) between the centre of block \(\mathbf{Q}\) and the \(50.0 \text{cm}\) mark and also the distance \(b\) between the centre of block \(\mathbf{Q}\) and the pivot. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 351, 918, 383]]<|/det|> He repeats the procedure for positions of block \(\mathbf{Q}\) at the \(90.0 \text{cm}\), \(85.0 \text{cm}\), \(80.0 \text{cm}\) and \(75.0 \text{cm}\) marks. His results are shown in Table 1.1. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[330, 428, 668, 606]]<|/det|> <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 397, 539, 413]]<|/det|> Table 1.1
position of Q /cma/cmb/cm
95.045.039.0
90.040.034.3
85.035.030.0
80.030.025.2
75.025.021.4

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 181, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 73, 918, 106]]<|/det|>
Plot a graph of \(a / \text{cm}\) (y-axis) against \(b / \text{cm}\) (x-axis). You do not need to start your axes at the origin (0, 0).

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[254, 147, 740, 492]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 572, 180, 590]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 572, 918, 605]]<|/det|>
Determine the gradient \(G\) of your line. Show clearly on the graph how you obtained the necessary information.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 699, 920, 717]]<|/det|>
<form>G = ................................................................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 733, 180, 752]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 730, 814, 758]]<|/det|>
Calculate the mass \(M_{\mathrm{R}}\) of the metre rule using the equation \(M_{\mathrm{R}} = \frac{M}{(G - 1)}\) ,

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 759, 918, 793]]<|/det|>
where \(M = 20 \text{g}\) . Record the value for \(M_{\text{R}}\) to a suitable number of significant figures for this experiment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[539, 891, 920, 910]]<|/det|>
<form>M_{\text{R}} = ........................................................................... [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 73, 148, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 918, 120]]<|/det|>
Two students carry out the experiment correctly but with different values for the mass of block \(\mathbf{Q}\) . One student obtains values of \(b\) that are larger than those obtained by the other student.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 135, 917, 166]]<|/det|>
State and explain whether the larger values of \(b\) are likely to produce a more accurate value for the mass of the metre rule.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[834, 274, 918, 291]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 11]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 73, 96, 92]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 73, 919, 107]]<|/det|> Some students are investigating how the volume of water affects the rate at which water in a beaker cools. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 120, 513, 138]]<|/det|> They are using the apparatus shown in Fig. 2.1. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[136, 147, 861, 320]]<|/det|> <|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 336, 532, 354]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 368, 918, 401]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 415, 754, 433]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 446, 918, 479]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 492, 750, 510]]<|/det|>

<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 73, 918, 107]]<|/det|>
Describe one precaution which should be taken to ensure that the temperature readings in the experiment are as accurate as possible.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[880, 151, 918, 168]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 180, 146, 199]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 180, 918, 215]]<|/det|>
Write a conclusion stating how the volume of water in the beaker affects the rate of cooling of the water. Justify your answer by reference to the results.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[880, 351, 918, 370]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 382, 148, 400]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 382, 180, 400]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 382, 918, 415]]<|/det|>
Using the results for \(100 \text{cm}^3\) of water, calculate the average rate of cooling \(x_1\) for the first 90 s of the experiment. Use the readings from the table and the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 425, 556, 456]]<|/det|>
\[x_{1} = \frac{\theta_{0} - \theta_{90}}{t},\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 473, 826, 508]]<|/det|>
where \(t = 90 \text{s}\) and \(\theta_0\) and \(\theta_{90}\) are the temperatures at time 0 and at time 90 s. Include the unit for the rate of cooling.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[547, 567, 918, 585]]<|/det|>
<form>x_{1} = ............................................................ [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 598, 181, 616]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 598, 918, 631]]<|/det|>
Using the results for \(100 \text{cm}^3\) of water, calculate the average rate of cooling \(x_2\) in the last 90 s of the experiment. Use the readings from the table and the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[434, 641, 564, 673]]<|/det|>
\[x_{2} = \frac{\theta_{90} - \theta_{180}}{t},\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 689, 876, 724]]<|/det|>
where \(t = 90 \text{s}\) and \(\theta_{90}\) and \(\theta_{180}\) are the temperatures at time 90 s and at time 180 s. Include the unit for the rate of cooling.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[542, 784, 918, 802]]<|/det|>
<form>x_{2} = ............................................................ [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 73, 146, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 272, 917, 325]]<|/det|>
Calculate the resistance \(R_{1}\) of lamp \(\mathbf{X}\) . Use the readings from **(b)** and **(c)(i)** and the equation \(R_{1} = \frac{V_{X}}{I_{S}}\) .

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 390, 870, 408]]<|/det|>

<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 421, 625, 440]]<|/det|>
The circuit components are to be rearranged so that

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[232, 453, 600, 470]]<|/det|>
lamps \(\mathbf{X}\) and \(\mathbf{Y}\) are connected in parallel

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[232, 470, 680, 485]]<|/det|>
the ammeter measures the current in lamp \(\mathbf{X}\) only

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[232, 485, 683, 500]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 515, 551, 532]]<|/det|>

<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[544, 176, 904, 196]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 274, 880, 290]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 415, 918, 432]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 446, 920, 463]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 11]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[78, 73, 94, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 73, 917, 106]]<|/det|>
A student is investigating the factors that affect the size of the crater (hole) a ball makes when it is dropped into sand.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 120, 917, 152]]<|/det|>
Plan an experiment which would enable you to investigate one factor which might affect the size of the crater.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 166, 393, 182]]<|/det|>
The apparatus available includes

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 197, 390, 228]]<|/det|>
metal balls of different sizes a tray of sand

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 243, 380, 259]]<|/det|>
Write a plan for the experiment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 274, 320, 290]]<|/det|>
In your plan you should:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 305, 484, 321]]<|/det|>
· state which factor is being investigated,

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 336, 533, 352]]<|/det|>
· state the key variables that you would control,

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 367, 460, 383]]<|/det|>
· list any additional apparatus needed,

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 398, 917, 429]]<|/det|>
· explain briefly how you would carry out the experiment including what would be measured and how this would be done,

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 444, 725, 460]]<|/det|>
· state the precautions which should be taken to obtain reliable results,

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 475, 682, 491]]<|/det|>
· suggest a suitable graph which could be drawn from the results.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 506, 575, 522]]<|/det|>
You may draw a diagram if it helps to explain your plan.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 83, 915, 730]]<|/det|> 
......
......
......
......
......
......
......
......
......
......
......
......
......
......
......
......
